TI IS MOBILITY THE MISSING LINK IN IMPROVING GIRLS' SCHOOLING IN PAKISTAN?
SO ASIAN POPULATION STUDIES
LA English
DT Article
DE rural Pakistan; girls' school enrolment and attrition; female mobility;
   schools; gender inequity
ID AUTONOMY; INDIA
AB This paper explores barriers leading to continuing low levels of girls' schooling in Pakistan. More specifically, and for rural areas, the authors examine the barriers stemming from culturally associated gender in schooling, focusing, in particular, on school availability and constraints on female mobility. Logistic regressions of enrolment and attrition using secondary data from the National Adolescent and Youth Survey show that even after taking school availability into account, girls in households allowing unrestricted mobility to school had 1.5 times higher odds of ever being enrolled than those who required an escort. Once in school, the need for an escort implied 1.6 times higher odds of dropping out. The paper concludes that while investment in girls' schools, and to secondary level, is paramount for starting and continuing in school, the potential benefits will only be fully realised with accompanying measures which facilitate rural girls' mobility.
C1 [Sathar, Zeba; ul Haque, Minhaj] Populat Council, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Sathar, Z (reprint author), Populat Council, House 7,St 62,Sect F-6-3, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI Characterization of cytotoxicity of airborne particulates from urban
   areas of Lahore
SO JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES-CHINA
LA English
DT Article
DE particulate matter; trace elements; in vitro toxicity
ID MATTER; MORTALITY
AB A number of species (organic and inorganic) in airborne particulates cause the toxicity to living being. The potential of in vitro test methods were explored for toxicity assessment of trace toxic elements (inorganic species) present in ambient air on human being (lungs). A year long sampling of airborne particles (PM2.5) was carried (April 2008 to March 2009) in Lahore, Pakistan. A total of thirty nine samples were collected on 47 mm Zefluor Teflon filter membranes and each was analysed to characterize for the elements: Sb, As, Be, Cd, Cr, Co, Pb, Mn, Hg using ICP-MS in water extract and total acid digestate. The samples cytotoxicity was also established using lung derived cells and MTS colorimetric assays. This generated dose response curves and IC50 values for the elemental mixtures identified on the Teflon filter membrane. The results indicated that even at low concentrations airborne elemental mixtures displayed an additive toxic effect.

TI Tripartite entanglement generation using cavity-QED and its dynamics in
   dissipative environments
SO JOURNAL OF MODERN OPTICS
LA English
DT Article
DE tripartite entanglement; entanglement generation; entanglement dynamics;
   sudden death of entanglement; quantum information processing; cavity QED
ID QUANTUM ENTANGLEMENT; TELEPORTATION; STATE; SEPARABILITY
AB We investigate the generation of tripartite field states inside the high-Q cavities using the cavity QED. The main goal is to successfully generate the entanglement in tripartite systems by passing two-level atoms through three identical high-Q cavities. Our scheme gives the successful generation of entangled tripartite W and GHZ states for pre-determined interaction times of atoms with the cavity fields. The dynamics of initial entangled states is studied as the system evolves in the dissipative environments.

TI User engagement with and attitudes towards an interactive SMS reminder
   system for patients with tuberculosis
SO JOURNAL OF TELEMEDICINE AND TELECARE
LA English
DT Article
ID RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED-TRIAL; ADHERENCE
AB We conducted a qualitative study to understand user perceptions, acceptability and engagement with an interactive SMS reminder system designed to improve treatment adherence for patients with tuberculosis (TB). Patients received daily reminders and were asked to respond after taking their medication. Non-responsive patients were sent up to three reminders a day. We enrolled 30 patients with TB who had access to a mobile phone and observed their engagement with the system for a one-month period. We also conducted semi-structured interviews with 24 patients to understand their experience with the system. Most patients found the reminders helpful and encouraging. The average response rate over the study period was 57%. However, it fell from a mean response rate of 62% during the first ten days to 49% during the last ten days. Response rates were higher amongst females, participants with some schooling, and participants who had sent an SMS message the week prior to enrolment. Non-responsiveness was associated with a lack of access to the owner of the mobile phone, problems with the mobile phone itself and literacy. Our pilot study suggests that interactive SMS reminders are an acceptable and appreciated method of supporting patients with TB in taking their medication.

TI Design and construction of prestressed arch using plastic shoppers waste
SO MATERIALES DE CONSTRUCCION
LA English
DT Article
DE compressed shoppers waste (CSW) block; structural arch; reuse;
   construction material; visco-elastic
AB Since the development of plastic in the last century, being versitile it has become very popular for diversified uses. The problem appears when these plastics, particularly shoppers are disposed as waste. The current reuse and recycling rates for the plastic shoppers waste are very low. Construction Industry has a great potential for the reuse of shoppers waste. Shoppers waste has been compressed to fabricate compressed shoppers waste (CSW) blocks. This study is related to an innovative reuse of CSW-blocks for the construction of prestressed structural arch. This paper is dedicated to the design and construction of structural arch using shoppers waste as a material.

TI Development of Electrostatic Inkjet Head by Integrating Metallic and
   Silica Capillaries for Stable Meniscus
SO MATERIALS AND MANUFACTURING PROCESSES
LA English
DT Article
DE Electrohydrodynamic printing (EHDP); Metallic enclosed glass (MEG);
   Vertically inserted electrode (VIE)
AB This article discusses the stability and analysis of meniscus for electrohydrodynamic printing (EHDP) system and printed results on flexible substrate. Conventionally, an electrode is inserted vertically into the fluid for generating electric field to induce charges that move towards the surface of the liquid. Disturbances and vibrations in the inkjet head, caused by the application of high electric potential is the main problem affecting the stability of the meniscus. Centralization, obstruction to the fluid flow, and the fixed position of vertically inserted electrode in the inkjet head adds to the complexity of the system design. In order to overcome all these limitations, a new technique has been developed and verified experimentally. A metallic capillary enclosed by tapered glass capillary results in removing obstructions to the fluid flow caused by inserting electrodes from top into the capillary head. The voltage applied in new setup for extraction is reduced around 1.2 kV, analyzed by simulation, and also verified by experiments. Electrode within the fluid channel remains at fixed point eliminating the positioning problems for repeatable parameters. With this head design, uniformity of the patterned lines is enhanced by obtaining a stable meniscus. Resolution of the printed patterns on flexible polyimide substrate is minimized. Ink having properties of 39.68 wt% of Ag nanoparticles, viscosity of 39 cps, and 5 dyn/cm of surface tension is used. All experiments are performed in ambient environment.

TI Mixed Convection Flow over an Unsteady Stretching Surface in a Porous
   Medium with Heat Source
SO MATHEMATICAL PROBLEMS IN ENGINEERING
LA English
DT Article
ID BOUNDARY-LAYERS; PERMEABLE SURFACE; MASS-TRANSFER; SHEET; SUCTION;
   FLUID; PLATE; TEMPERATURE; GENERATION; INJECTION
AB This paper deals with the analysis of an unsteady mixed convection flow of a fluid saturated porous medium adjacent to heated/cooled semi-infinite stretching vertical sheet in the presence of heat source. The unsteadiness in the flow is caused by continuous stretching of the sheet and continuous increase in the surface temperature. We present the analytical and numerical solutions of the problem. The effects of emerging parameters on field quantities are examined and discussed.
C1 [Imran, Syed Muhammad; Asghar, Saleem; Mushtaq, Muhammad] COMSATS Inst Informat Technol, Dept Math, Islamabad 44000, Pakistan.

TI Synthesis, Characterization, and Study of Thermal and Liquid Crystalline
   Properties of Poly(4-(6-(4-vinylphenoxy)hexyloxy)benzoic Acid)
SO MOLECULAR CRYSTALS AND LIQUID CRYSTALS
LA English
DT Article
DE H-bonded core; liquid crystalline polymer; thermal properties
AB Poly(4-vinylphenol) was modified to poly(4-(6-(4-vinylphenoxy)hexyloxy)benzoic acid) for incorporating a flexible hexamethylene side chain with a terminal benzoic acid moiety to induce liquid crystallinity. The rigid core is generated through hydrogen bonding (H-bonding) between the pendant benzoic acid groups. The thermal stability of the modified polymer was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), whereas differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and polarizing optical microscopy (POM) were used to investigate the liquid crystalline behavior. The polymer exhibits mesomorphism over a wide temperature range.

TI Antimicrobial Activities of Novel Bis-Piperidinium Compounds
SO POLISH JOURNAL OF MICROBIOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
DE bis-piperidinium; quaternary ammonium; piperidinium; antimicrobial
   activity
ID QUATERNARY AMMONIUM
AB The antimicrobial activity of two new series of bis-piperidinium compounds, with alkyl chains of different length, against bacterial (Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus subtilis) and fungal strains (Aspergillus flavus, Aspergillus niger, Rhodolorula rubera, Lipomyces lopofera and Candida albicans), are described. Antimicrobial activities of the synthesized compounds were compared to that of dodecyltrimethylammonium chloride. Bis-piperidinium salts containing 12-16 carbon side chains showed better antimicrobial properties when compared to the standard dodecyltrimethylammonium chloride.

AF Ali, Mubarak
   Urgen, Mustafa
TI Tantalum carbide-graphite composite film synthesized by hot-filament
   chemical vapor deposition
SO PURE AND APPLIED CHEMISTRY
LA English
DT Article
DE chemical vapor deposition; composite materials; crystal structures;
   interfaces; materials science
ID THIN-FILMS; TAC; DIAMOND; TA2C
AB A composite film of tantalum carbide (TaC)-graphite was synthesized on etched Si using thermal evaporation of Ta followed by C/H chemical vapor deposition (CVD). In the present study, Ta wire 0.5 mm in diameter was electrically heated without carburizing. Under high current conditions, filaments were thermally evaporated and interacted with chemically decomposed C, forming a composite film of TaC-graphite deposits on the substrates. The influence of chamber pressure, substrate temperature, and methane concentration on the film properties has been studied. By increasing chamber pressure from 25 to 100 torr in a gas mixture of H and methane (containing 3 % methane), the morphology of films changed with an increased growth rate and surface roughness. Increasing the methane concentration in the mixture resulted in broadening of X-ray diffraction (XRD) peaks, increase in film thickness, and coarsening of grains, along with formation of clusters. The growth rates of the films produced at a substrate temperature of 950 degrees C were lower than those deposited at 850 degrees C. Their grain sizes were bigger and exhibited a dense structure with higher surface roughness.

PT J
AU Akram, M
AF Akram, Muhammad
TI EXCHANGE RATE REGIMES AND CURRENCY BEHAVIOURS IN PAKISTAN: AN
   EXPLORATORY ACCOUNT
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE exchange rate regimes; Pak rupee; Pakistan; exports
ID POLICY
AB The objective of this study is to explore the exchange rate regimes and PKR (Pak rupee) behaviours prevailed under such regimes in the economy of Pakistan since its inception. It is concluded that PKR was influenced unnecessarily by GBP and USD during the fixed exchange rate regime. Moreover, Pakistan used its currency as a tool to boost up its exports, and too much focus was given on this tool instead of paying more attention to other core issues related to exports. This study provides an opportunity for policy makers and researchers to understand PKR behaviour under various exchange rate regimes.

TI AN EMPIRICAL STUDY OF BARRIERS IN IMPLEMENTING TOTAL QUALITY MANAGEMENT
   IN SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS IN PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE total quality management; barriers; services; Pakistan
ID TQM IMPLEMENTATION; OBSTACLES; TRANSFORMATION; PITFALLS
AB The purpose of this study is to investigate empirically the barriers of total quality management implementation experienced by service organizations in Pakistan. Structured questionnaire was used to collect the data from a sample of 120 managers. The results identified lack of planning, lack of efficient human resources practices, inadequate infrastructure for total quality management, lack of support from leadership, and lack of customer focus as significant barriers to implementing this initiative. The results provided an opportunity to quality managers, human resources practitioners, and other professionals to pursue appropriate intervention strategies to offset the effects of these barriers.

TI HOW INDIVIDUAL SOCIAL VALUES STIMULATE CONSUMER PURCHASE DECISION
   INVOLVEMENT AND COMPULSIVE BUYING BEHAVIOR: A PATH BY PATH MIULTIGROUPS
   ANALYSIS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE social values; purchase involvement; compulsive buying behavior;
   multigroup analysis; moderator
ID COMORBIDITY
AB The paper investigates how individual susceptibility impacts consumer characteristics and compulsive buying behavior. Specifically, it explores the relationship between individual social values (IVSs), purchase decision involvement (PDI) and compulsive buying behavior (CBB) in Pakistan with respect to structural equation modeling. The data was collected from 641 consumers.

TI Role of Ultrasound and Ultrasound-Guided Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology
   for Axillary Lymph Node Evaluation in Breast Cancer Patients:
   Correlation with Primary Tumor Size and Positive Lymph Node Number
SO BREAST CARE
LA English
DT Article
DE Breast cancer; Ultrasound; Lymph nodes; Fine-needle aspiration
ID METASTASIS; DISSECTION; BIOPSY
AB Objectives: To evaluate the efficacy of ultrasound (US) and US-guided fine-needle aspiration (US-FNA) for axillary nodal staging in breast cancer patients. Methods: A retrospective study of breast cancer patients at our institution from January 2007 to December 2009 revealed 449 cases in which axillary US was performed. The US appearance of the axillary lymph nodes was divided into 4 categories: suspicious, borderline, benign, and not visible. The results were compared with the final pathologic outcome and correlated with the tumor size on US and the pathologic nodal stage (pN). Results: Among the 449 patients, the lymph nodes were: not visualized in 124, suspicious in 180, borderline in 39, and benign in 106 cases. The overall sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and accuracy of US alone and combined US/US-FNA was 69.1%, 83.3%, 86.8%, 63%, and 74.6% and 69.1%, 100%, 100%, 67.2%, and 81.1%, respectively. The sensitivity of US increased with increasing tumor size and pN. A negative or benign US (combined n = 230) was associated with the pN0, pN1, pN2, and pN3 stage in 146, 66, 13, and 5 cases, respectively. Conclusions: Axillary staging using US criteria is about 70% sensitive and its sensitivity increases with increasing tumor size and pN stage.
C1 [Manzoor, Muhammad U.; Irshad, Abid] Med Univ S Carolina, Dept Radiol, Charleston, SC 29425 USA.

TI The Mask of Odd Points n-Ary Interpolating Subdivision Scheme
SO JOURNAL OF APPLIED MATHEMATICS
LA English
DT Article
AB We present an explicit formula for the mask of odd points n-ary, for any odd n >= 3, interpolating subdivision schemes. This formula provides the mask of lower and higher arity schemes. The 3-point and 5-point a-ary schemes introduced by Lian, 2008, and (2m + 1)-point a-ary schemes introduced by, Lian, 2009, are special cases of our explicit formula. Moreover, other well-known existing odd point n-ary schemes including the schemes introduced by Zheng et al., 2009, can easily be generated by our formula. In addition, error bounds between subdivision curves and control polygons of schemes are computed. It has been noticed that error bounds decrease when the complexity of the scheme decreases and vice versa. Also, as we increase arity of the schemes the error bounds decrease. Furthermore, we present brief comparison of total absolute curvature of subdivision schemes having different arity with different complexity. Convexity preservation property of scheme is also presented.

TI Configuration change of liquid crystal microdroplets coated with a novel
   polyacrylic acid block liquid crystalline polymer by protein adsorption
SO LAB ON A CHIP
LA English
DT Article
ID REAL-TIME; ORDERING TRANSITIONS; SURFACES; INTERFACES; DROPLETS;
   BINDING; SENSOR; MICROFLUIDICS; ORIENTATIONS; TEMPERATURE
AB 4-cyano-4'-pentylbiphenyl (5CB) microdroplets coated with PAA-b-LCP were successfully made via microfluidics. Their functionalized interfaces were examined for lysozyme and bovine serum albumin detection, which could be easily visualized with an optical microscope under crossed polarizers by the radial-to-bipolar configurational change of the 5CB. This transition was strongly dependent on the electrostatic states of the proteins and PAA chains, which were controlled by the pH of the water. This study demonstrated a simple approach for the development of a liquid crystal-based sensor for label-free detection of proteins, which may have diverse applications in various biomedical fields.

TI Pyrrole versus quinoline formation in the palladium catalyzed reaction
   of 2-alkynyl-3-bromothiophenes and 2-alkynyl-3-bromofurans with
   anilines. A combined experimental and computational study
SO ORGANIC & BIOMOLECULAR CHEMISTRY
LA English
DT Article
ID HIGHLY EFFICIENT SYNTHESIS; EFFECTIVE CORE POTENTIALS; INTERNAL ALKYNES;
   CRYPTOLEPIS-SANGUINOLENTA; REGIOSELECTIVE SYNTHESIS; MOLECULAR
   CALCULATIONS; AROMATIC HETEROCYCLES; IN-VITRO; DERIVATIVES; ANNULATION
AB Benzofuroquinolines were prepared by a new type of Pd catalyzed annulation reaction. In the first step, 2-alkynyl-3-bromobenzofurans were prepared by Sonogashira reactions of 2,3-dibromobenzofuran. Their Pd catalyzed reaction with electron-rich anilines afforded benzofuroquinolines by a domino C-N coupling/annulation process. This reaction proceeds as a C,N-cyclization via the nitrogen atom and the ortho-carbon of the aniline. Similarly, furoquinolines were prepared from 2,3-dibromofuran. In contrast, benzo-furopyrroles and furopyrroles were formed by N,N-cyclization when electron-poor anilines were used. Earlier, we reported results related to the thiophene and benzothiophene series. Quinolines were formed from 2,3-dibromobenzothiophene when electron rich anilines were used. In contrast, pyrroles were obtained in the case of electron-poor anilines. On the other hand, pyrroles were generally obtained, not depending on the type of aniline, when 2,3-dibromothiophene was employed as the starting material. In the present article, a detailed DFT study related to the mechanism ( quinoline versus pyrrole formation) is reported which provides a rationalization of the selectivities observed for the furan, benzofuran, thiophene and benzothiophene series and for the different selectivities observed for electron-rich and -poor anilines.

PT J
AU Ali, A

   Khan, Muhammad Shoaib
TI In vivo evaluation: the effects of a cream containing Acacia bark
   extract on skin melanin and erythema content
SO POSTEPY DERMATOLOGII I ALERGOLOGII
LA English
DT Article
DE Acacia nilotica; active cream; melanin; erythema
ID ANTIOXIDANT; PARAMETERS
AB Introduction: Phenolic compounds have inhibitory effects on tyrosinase and inflammatory activities which lead to reduction in the melanin and erythema content. This is important for hyperpigmentation, dermatitis and other oxidative stress diseases.
   Aim: Investigation of the effects of a cream containing phenolic-rich extract of Acacia bark on the human skin melanin and erythema content.
   Material and methods: Eleven healthy male volunteers were analyzed and treated with active cream versus base for a period of three months by non-invasive bioengineering techniques.
   Results: No serious adverse effects were observed after patch testing. Base showed insignificant results and active cream showed a significant decrease in skin melanin and erythema content after statistically applied ANOVA.
   Conclusions: Our results show that the Acacia bark extract represents a valuable source of phenolic compounds produced naturally. Treatments of human skin with active cream containing phenolic-rich Acacia bark extract significantly reduce skin melanin and erythema in vivo and could be used for topical treatment of hyperpigmentation and dermatitis.

TI Effect of Recycled Polypropylene on the Mechanical and Rheological
   Properties of Polypropylene-NBR Thermoplastic Vulcanisates
SO PROGRESS IN RUBBER PLASTICS AND RECYCLING TECHNOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
DE Polymer recycling; Thermoplastic vulcanisates; Polymer waste; Polymer
   blends
ID TENSILE YIELD BEHAVIOR; DYNAMIC CROSS-LINKING; NITRILE-RUBBER;
   ISOTACTIC-POLYPROPYLENE; BLENDS; MORPHOLOGY; RATIO
AB Virgin polypropylene (PP), recycled polypropylene (RPP) and acrylonitrile butadiene rubber (NBR) were mixed together to prepare ternary blends (PP/RPP/NBR) of thermoplastic vulcanisates (TPVs). The blends comprised 30 parts per hundred (phr) NBR and 70 phr PP and RPP Sulphur was used to dynamically crosslink the NBR during the blending process. Maleic anhydride grafted polypropylene (MA-g-PP) was used as compatibiliser to enhance the interaction of the polypropylene and the rubber In this study, the loading of RPP in the TPVs was varied and the effects on mechanical and rheological properties were studied. The hardness and the tensile strength of the TPVs increased upon increasing the RPP loading. The RPP exhibited an adverse effect on elongation-at-break of the vulcanisates, with the pseudo-plastic flow behaviour and the viscosity of the vulcanisates increasing with the increased loading of RPP.
C1 [Mamoor, G. M.; Irfan, Muhammad S.; Gill, Yasir Q.; Qaiser, Asif A.; Saeed, Farhan] Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Polymer & Proc Engn, Lahore, Pakistan.
RP Mamoor, GM (reprint author), Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Polymer & Proc Engn, GT Rd, Lahore, Pakistan.
EM mamoorgm@uet.edu.pk

TI Microstrip Antenna Array for Beamforming Systems
SO PRZEGLAD ELEKTROTECHNICZNY
LA English
DT Article
DE Antenna Array; Beamforming; Mutual Coupling; IEEE WLAN Standard
ID IMPACT
AB A dual and quad element antenna array resonating at 2.4 GHz with narrow beam is proposed in this paper. An intention to put forward this work is to make use of microstrip patch antennas in beamforming to form directional beams in analog and digital domains; reducing co-channel/multipath interferences and improving Quality of Service (QoS) for senor arrays and 3G wireless networks. The size of dual and quad element antenna array is 60 x 130 mm2 and 60 x 240 mm2 respectively. Simulations in HFSS (High Frequency Structure Simulator) showed least mutual coupling among adjacent elements and prototypes have been fabricated using FR4 to verify the efficiency of the presented work for IEEE 802.11b/g WLAN standards.

TI MULTI-COMPONENT QUANTITATION OF LORATADINE, PSEUDOEPHEDRINE AND
   PARACETAMOL IN PLASMA AND PHARMACEUTICAL FORMULATIONS WITH LIQUID
   CHROMATOGRAPHY-TANDEM MASS SPECTROMETRY UTILIZING A MONOLITHIC COLUMN
SO QUIMICA NOVA
LA English
DT Article
DE antihistamines; decongestants; liquid chromatography-tandem MS
ID ELECTROSPRAY-IONIZATION; IN-VITRO; CHLORPHENIRAMINE
AB The purpose of this study was to develop a rapid, simple and sensitive quantitation method for pseudoephedrine (PSE), paracetamol (PAR) and loratadine (LOR) in plasma and pharmaceuticals using liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry with a monolithic column. Separation was achieved using a gradient composition of methanol-0.1% formic acid at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min(-1). Mass spectral transitions were recorded in SRM mode. System validation was evaluated for precision, specificity and linearity. Limit of detection for pseudoephediine, paracetamol, and loratadine were determined to be 3.14, 1.86 and 1.44 ng mL(-1) respectively, allowing easy determination in plasma with % recovery of 93.12 to 101.56%.
C1 [Abro, Kamran; Memon, Najma; Bhanger, M. I.] Univ Sindh Jamshoro, Natl Ctr Excellence Analyt Chem, Jamshoro 76080, Pakistan.
   [Abro, Kamran; Perveen, Shahnaz; Kandhro, Aftab] Pakistan Council Sci & Ind Res Labs Complex, Karachi 75280, Pakistan.

TI ECONOMIC FREEDOM AND EQUITY MARKET LIQUIDITY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE economic freedom; market liquidity; stock market return; stock market
   volatility
ID STOCK
AB It is widely believed that economic freedom is a vital factor in determining the wellbeing of people. Countries with greater economic freedom become wealthier and their financial markets become stable. The paper measures the impact of the economic freedom on the liquidity of stock market of the country. We use the data for 77 countries from 1996 to 2009. The analysis reveals that some of the components of economic freedom have significant positive impact on the liquidity of stock market. When the data is separately taken for the period 2007-2009 (crisis), the results show that the index of economic freedom has significant impact on the liquidity of stock market. The above demonstrates that the countries with higher economic freedom maintain better liquidity of their stock markets.

TI FACTORS AFFECTING BRAND LOYALTY: A PERSPECTIVE OF FAST FOOD RESTAURANTS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE brand loyalty; brand knowledge; product quality; word of mouth; fast
   food restaurants
ID CORPORATE SOCIAL-RESPONSIBILITY; BEHAVIOR; RESPONSES; PRODUCT; IMPACT;
   LINK
AB The present study examines different key factors affecting brand loyalty in a developing country like Pakistan. The study focuses on the following aspects: Brand Knowledge, Brand Social Responsibility, Brand Name, Product Quality, Word of Mouth and Brand Trust. The results reveal that all the factors are significantly related to Brand Trust except Word of Mouth. Brand Trust is partially correlated with Brand Loyalty.

TI RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DECISION MAKING STYLES AND CONSUMER BEHAVIOR
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE decision making style; consumer behavior; significant relationship;
   perfectionism; fashion
AB The objective of this study is to identify different factors that impact consumer behavior on the basis of a decision making style. The sample size of this study was 250 questionnaires. The data were collected through a 5-point Liken scale questionnaire. SPSS was used to analyze the data. Correlation and multiple regression were performed to measure the relationship between independent and dependent variables; independent sample t-test was applied to test the difference between male and female decision making styles. This study concludes there is a significant relationship between male and female decision making style and female respondents are more likely to assert that decision making styles influence consumer behavior. All the independent variables have significant positive relationship with consumer behavior.

TI INVESTMENT APPRAISAL TECHNIQUES AND CONSTRAINTS ON CAPITAL INVESTMENT
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE investment appraisal techniques; Pakistani corporate sector; long-term
   profitability; investment opportunities
ID ACQUIRING FIRMS; UNCERTAINTY; PERFORMANCE; RETURNS
AB The objective of this study is to determine the level of application and perception of finance executives and analysts regarding the investment appraisal techniques in Pakistani corporate sector in the light of theory. This study also investigates major constraints on capital investment. In total 63 questionnaires were distributed in different cities of Pakistan (Islamabad, Rawalpindi, Lahore, Multan and Faisalabad) but only 37 properly filled questionnaires were processed; the potential respondents were finance executives and Chief Financial Officers (CFOs) of companies. The companies listed at KSE related to 10 leading sectors were the participants of this study. It is concluded that corporate managers have the awareness about the worth of investment appraisal techniques and consider these techniques important for long term profitability and survival of the company. It is also concluded that the availability of finance, lack of profitable investment opportunities and the attitude of senior management are the major constraints on capital investment.

TI DETERMINANTS OF FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES: A CONCEPTUAL STUDY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE selection of financial management practices; earnings management;
   stakeholder theory; behavioral factors; corporate social disclosure;
   organizational performance; shareholder wealth maximization
ID PAKISTANI CORPORATE SECTOR; CAPITAL STRUCTURE; REAL OPTIONS; FIRMS;
   PERFORMANCE; INVESTMENT; GOVERNANCE; DISCLOSURE; DECISIONS; INVESTORS
AB The purpose of this study is to investigate various factors (uncertainty, corporate social disclosure and stakeholder) that impact the selection of financial management practices. Further, this study attempts to explore the impact of financial management practices and earnings management on firm performance. In order to achieve the objective, a conceptual model has been developed based on previous theories and empirical literature. The findings of the study would be quite beneficial for capital providers - lenders and shareholders - who would like to use their funds for financial practices. On the other hand, capital providers will be hesitant to provide capital to those firms which do not use appropriate financial practices and have poor transparency.

TI INDIVIDUAL COMPANY RELATED ECONOMIC AND INVESTMENT BEHAVIOR
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE herding behaviour; development of positive attitude; customers,
   individual investors
ID BRAND LOYALTY; IDENTITY; IDENTIFICATION; MARKET; UK
AB This study creates links between individuals who are customers and investors of a company. Main area of the study is the positive behavior of such individuals towards a company. How to develop positive attitude of individuals towards a company? How customers' economic behavior converts into investment behavior and how investment behavior of investors/individuals may be transferred into economic behavior? This study further investigates the effects of individuals positive attitude on others at the same markets. This means effects of positive behavior and development of herding behavior of others at the same market especially the stock exchange of Pakistan.

TI DETERMINANTS OF INTEREST RATE SPREAD: AN EMPIRICAL EXPLANATION
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE technology; determinants of IRS; market size; banking sector
ID BANKING
AB This study aims to contribute to the research on determinants of the IRS by adding technology as a key factor at the bank level. Empirical result of this study on the banking sector of Pakistan reveals the key determinants of IRS. They are operating costs, non-interest revenue, concentration ratio, market size, corruption, domestic borrowing, fiscal deficit, exchange rate, inflation, money circulation and government expenditure.

TI IMPACT OF TECHNOLOGY ON INTEREST RATE: EVIDENCE FROM THE BANKING SECTOR
   OF PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE competitive environment; local banks; policy makers
ID COMPETITION
AB The impact of technology on IRS has not yet been studied in Pakistani banking sector. This study is an attempt to fill this gap. Both banks and policy makers should devise a strategy to encourage adoption of new technologies, and banks should apply charges on technological services. It is also important to educate customers about the technology adoption. Secondly, lower fiscal deficit is advisable to decrease the dependency on local banks. The government should reduce the deficit by decreasing the non-developing expenditures. Finally, banks in a country with a more competitive environment have smaller IRS. Thus, the government should also focus on breaking the existing organized cartel in the banking sector.

TI EFFECTS OF ORGANIZATIONAL ETHICS ON TURNOVER INTENTIONS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE organizational ethics; employee turnover; intentention to leave a job
ID JOB TURNOVER
AB This research investigates the influence of organizational ethics on the employee turnover intentions. Responses from 169 employees, who work for different organizations, are used to test the structural model that examines the process through which organizational ethics affects the employee turnover intentions. The results of this investigation provides support for the conjecture that organizational ethics is an important factor which influences the employee turnover intentions. Results reveal that an employee would be less likely to leave an organization if organizational ethical practices are followed.
C1 [Khan, Asad; Khattak, Fawad Aslam] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

RP Khan, A (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI CRUCIAL HR PRACTICES FOR EMPLOYEE RETENTION IN ECONOMIC INSTABILITY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE employee retention; HR practices; trust; communication
ID HUMAN-RESOURCES; ENGAGEMENT; TALENT; TRUST; WORK
AB This study focuses on employees retention to increase competitiveness of an organization. The focus is made on the HR practices which require less financial resources but are very efficient. Therefore, communication, job enrichment and trust are taken as independent variables which influence retention of employees. This study discusses the impact of 3 independent variables on employee engagement. They are: trust, communication and job enrichment. A suggestion drawn from the literature survey is that employee retention could be managed using engagement as a bedrock of any HR strategy.

TI MEDIATING ROLE OF EMPLOYEE PERFORMANCE AND RETENTION IN TRAINING AND
   ORGANIZATIONAL PERFORMANCE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE organizational performance; training; employee performance; employee
   retention; pharmaceutical industry
ID RESOURCE MANAGEMENT-PRACTICES; JOB-SATISFACTION; LEVEL ANALYSIS;
   TURNOVER; IMPACT; FIRM; PRODUCTIVITY
AB This study examines the relationship between training development and organizational performance. This study measures the relationship between training and organizational performance and the mediating impact of employee performance and employee retention on the overall organizational performance. Training and development can be used to increase the employee retention. For pharmaceutical industry of Pakistan the relationship between employee retention and organizational performance is insignificant.

TI SOME NEW EVIDENCE ON DETERMINANTS OF FOREIGN DIRECT INVESTMENT: A CASE
   STUDY OF PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE foreign direct investment (FDI); domestic investment; political risk;
   trade openness; output
ID GROWTH
AB Foreign direct investment (FDI) is often considered as an important tool of economic growth in developing countries. It affects economic growth by stimulating domestic investment, increasing human capital formation and facilitating the technology transfer. After 1980s importance of FDI increased due to creation of new markets, advancement of technologies and development of efficient production and sales globally. We have tested two regimes data: democratic (1990-1999) and military (2000-2007). The result obtained suggests that domestic investment is independent of the level of FDI inflows. In other words, it implies that a change in domestic investment is not influenced by FDI inflows. However, the Granger causality findings suggest that the current government expenditures influence the amount of FDI in future. In Pakistan trade openness is negatively associated with FDI.
C1 [Haq, Ayaz Ul; Sahto, Qaimdin] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Niazi, Ghulam Shabbir Khan] Quaid I Azam Univ, Quaid I Azam Sch Management Sci, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Haq, AU (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI IMPACT OF JCW ON ORGANIZATIONAL COMMITMENT IN FIVE-STAR HOTELS: A
   QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE organizational commitment; hotel industry; employee involvement;
   employer-employee relation; growth opportunities
AB The paper investigates the level of organizational commitment of management in hospitality sector. It also explores the factors affecting organizational commitment and the fit between employer-employee relationships resulting in the growth of hotel sector. Organizational commitment is the combination of feelings, expectations and beliefs that employees have for their organization. Workers who show commitment to their organizations are less likely to leave and might be more likely to score high on organizational citizenship behavior (OCB). Organizational commitment in the hospitality sector is the psychological affection and affiliation of an employee to a hotel in which he/she works. Committed and satisfied employees always focus on qualitative work to enhance customer satisfaction, profitability and growth. Hotel employers should also reciprocate the demand of their employees. They should put efforts to retain them. These efforts include many things like providing supportive supervisors, growth opportunities, balance between work and life, congenial work environment etc.
C1 [Abbasi, Ayesha; Amjad, Muhammad Usman] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Amjad, MU (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

AB This study investigates the influence of incentives provided by a retailer (during a customer loyalty program) to its customers on their loyalty and changes in behavior. TI EXPLORATION OF FACTORS CREATING POSITIVE ATTITUDE OF PAKISTANI CUSTOMERS
   TO MOBILE ADVERTISING
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE mobile advertising; customer attitude; monetary benefits; message
   content, customer control
AB This study aims to investigate the influence of 3 important factors (message content, customer control and monetary benefits) on customers' attitude to mobile advertising. The literature is supported with the help of previous research work and studies done in the field of mobile advertising. This study is done in the Pakistani context and explores how these 3 factors create positive attitude of Pakistani customers to mobile advertising. Implications for managers and future research directions are presented in the study.

TI EFFECTS OF POSITIVE AND NEGATIVE AD-EVOKED ASSOCIATIONS ON PURCHASE
   INTENTION
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE associations; purchase intention; cognitive capacity; ad-evoked
   association; consumer behavior
ID CONSUMER
AB This paper contributes to the research on cognitive capacity theory. It studies the effects of positive and negative ad-associations on consumer's purchase intention. The authors suggest that purchase intention is closely related to actual behavior, as ultimate goal of any company is to sell its products. The paper suggests a model on the effects of positive and negative ad-evoked associations on purchase intention. Extensive research is done on the effects of ad-evoked associations. Since most of the research is focused on brand attitude, this study analyses the effects of ad-evoked association on purchase intention which is closely related to actual consumer behavior, especially in developing countries like Pakistan.

TI VALUES ASSOCIATED WITH CSR, THEIR IMPACT ON PURCHASE INTENTIONS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE corporate social responsibility; consumer behavior; purchase intentions;
   social values; emotional values
ID CORPORATE SOCIAL-RESPONSIBILITY; CONSUMER RESPONSES; INITIATIVES;
   COMPANIES; PRODUCTS; BRAND; FIT
AB This study adds to the knowledge of values generated by CSR activities. A lot of research is done on CSR and outcomes of CSR. Values associated with CSR activities have also been an area of interest for researchers. However, this study explores a dimension that is not only unique but also close to actual behavior. The author suggests that in the current scenario of economic recession, both consumers and organizations want a return. Organizations are struggling for every purchase, therefore in order to influence consumers purchase behavior they should provide them what they want, and that is of value. The author further suggests that values associated with CSR impact purchase intention positively.

TI RECOGNIZING THE EFFECTS OF CONFLICTS IN DIVERSE ENVIRONMENT ON
   RELATIONSHIP PERFORMANCE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE organizational culture; communicstion; trust; conflict
ID ORGANIZATIONAL CULTURE; FIRM PERFORMANCE; DEMOGRAPHY; OUTCOMES;
   COMMUNICATION; MANAGEMENT; COHESION; IMPACT; LEVEL; TIME
AB Authors broaden the concept of previous research, arguing that the diverse culture in organization has positive and negative consequences. A diverse team in an organization can create a lot of conflicts and may lead to lower level of relationship performance among employees as well as in diverse teams. However, diversity in an organization can boost up the relationship performance by providing different sort of opinions and new ideologies of work, which enhance the group's performance and lead to greater productivity. The rationale of this study is to elaborate the concepts of the diverse culture environment and find the factors affecting the relationship performance by a theoretical justification. The model proposed argues that the conflict is a key factor that has a strong effect on relationship performance.

TI A LAYER BY LAYER INVESTIGATION TO IDENTIFY THE PROBLEM EPICENTER:
   EPICENTER MODEL OF EXPLORATORY RESEARCH FOR NOVICE RESEARCHERS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE exploratory; phenomena; focal point; epicenter; surface; mantle; core
AB This article introduces the epicenter model of exploratory research to guide both academic researchers and practitioners, beginners especially, in conducting exploratory research. Epicenter model of exploratory research consists of 3 layers i.e. surface, mantle and core to diagnose the invisible, confusing and unclear research or management problem. It is a general but systematic and sequential theoretical framework showing how to carry out exploratory studies in an organized manner. It shows how researchers can identify and analyze issues at Afferent levels of exploration to reach the target problem.

TI COMPARATIVE IMPACT OF DIFFERENT DOMAINS OF SELF-CONCEPT ON CONSUMERS'
   BRAND SELECTION DECISION
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE self-concept; congruity; brand selection
ID PERSONALITY; CONGRUENCE; ATTACHMENT; VALIDITY
AB To be seen unique from others, express inner self, and enhance private and public image, individuals choose such brands, which are in line with their self-concept. This study examined the comparative influence of 4 domains of self-concept, i.e. actual, ideal, social and ideal social self-concepts on the consumers brand selection purchase decision in apparel category. Results reveal some new consumer insights, which have important implications for practitioners.

TI CONSUMER PERCEPTION IN RESPONSE TO E-MARKETING STIMULI: THE IMPACT OF
   BRAND SALIENCE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE e-marketing; e-marketing stimuli; consumer perception; brand salience;
   hot and cold media
ID ELECTRONIC COMMERCE; PERCEIVED RISK
AB The objective of the study is to contrast the effects of stimuli coming from traditional media carrier platforms with stimuli coming through e-marketing carrier platforms. Another main objective was to study the impact of brand salience on consumer perception in the e-marketing frame. An experimental survey design is used in this study. E-marketing stimuli are contrasted from traditional stimuli and found to have varying effects in comparison. Traditional media on its own still has a stronger effect on consumer perception. Brand salience is found to have significant effect on perception formation in response to e-marketing stimuli. Hot media platforms of SMS and newspaper have a much stronger and significant effect on all aspects of consumer perception as compared to colder media platforms of web banner ad, e-mail and platform of TV.
C1 [Qureshi, Imran Munawar; Batool, Iram] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Shamim, Amjad] Virtual Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Batool, Iram] UIMS PMAS Univ Arid Agr, Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

TI MEASURING THE EFFECT OF E-MARKETING STIMULI ON CONSUMER PERCEPTION: A
   SCALE DEVELOPMENT STUDY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE e-marketing; e-marketing stimuli; consumer perception
ID USER ACCEPTANCE; TECHNOLOGY
AB This paper presents the scale development effort, as apart of a wider study conducted to determine the effect of e-marketing stimuli on the psychological construct of consumer perception. ID INTERNATIONAL-TRADE; RATE VOLATILITY; RISK
AB Exports of any country serve as a backbone in its development. This study examines the effect of interest rate, inflation and exchange rate on cotton exports in Pakistani economic context. Secondary data is used to check the relationship by unit root test and co-integration tests.

TI CONFLICT IS NOT PROBLEMATIC BUT RATHER IT PROMOTES COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE
   AND PERFORMANCE: PERSPECTIVE OF PAKISTANI WORK TEAMS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE conflict; work teams; organizational performance; strategic advantage;
   innovation
ID RESOURCE-BASED VIEW; ORGANIZATIONAL PERFORMANCE; INNOVATION; MANAGEMENT;
   FIRM; CHINA; ORIENTATION; DIMENSIONS; MODEL
AB Traditionally, conflict has been regarded from a negative perspective. It is considered as a problematic phenomenon. Further, there is an ongoing debate whether organizations should rely on individuals or incorporate teams. The study focuses on team contribution towards managing conflict and individual problem solving. Identification and solution of individual problem solving results in innovation which in turn enables organizations to gain competitive position and improve the overall performance. The study constructs a model which measures the effect of conflict management approaches on innovation and the impact of innovation on organizational competitive position and performance. The results of this study would prove beneficial for organizations to turn negative conflict problem into a positive performance and competitive advantage.

TI STOCK PRICE AND EXCHANGE RATE RELATIONSHIP: PRE- AND POST FINANCIAL
   CRISIS (2007) ANALYSIS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE financial crisis; exchange rate; KSE 100; granger; cointegration
ID RATE EXPOSURE
AB Stock markets are deemed to represent the overall economy of a country and are of prime interest for scholars and practitioners. There have been consistent efforts to explore the factors that influence stock prices (SP). This study examines the relationship between stock prices and exchange rate (XR) in Pakistan with regard to US Dollars. It contributes significantly to the literature by investigating this relationship before and after the financial crisis of 2007. Granger causality and cointegration tests are used to gauge this relationship. Empirical findings show no relation between SP & XR in Pakistan. This study provides guidelines for financial managers on appreciating the XR fluctuations while making portfolio decisions.
C1 [Iqbal, Jamshed; Nadeem, Waciar; Zakriya, Muhammad] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Tanveer, Muhammad Muzammil] Natl Univ Sci & Technol, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Iqbal, J (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI WHY INVESTORS DECEIVE THEMSELVES: COGNITIVE BIASES OF PAKISTANI
   INVESTORS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE investor behavior; knowledge sharing; subjective norm; stock market
   efficiency; knowledge creation
ID ORGANIZATIONAL CITIZENSHIP BEHAVIOR; JOB-PERFORMANCE; PERSONALITY;
   DETERMINANTS
AB Knowledge creation is initiated when people move against the set norms and beliefs. This newly created knowledge results in knowledge sharing. This study attempts to have a deeper understanding of this phenomenon. Pakistani stock market has been creating knowledge since it is one of the most volatile market of the world and sometimes is able to deviate the fundamental concepts of finance. The present endeavor investigates the knowledge sharing intentions and behavior of individual investors. For this purpose, individual and environmental factors that encourage knowledge sharing have been used. The study aims at creating awareness of individual investors regarding knowledge sharing, as well as assisting the stock market to operate more efficiently through its participants.

TI LONG-RUN RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN POVERTY AND MACROECONOMIC VARIABLES IN
   PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE economic indicators; causality; literacy rate; population growth;
   Johansen's cointegration
ID GROWTH
AB This study examines the long-run relationship between poverty and economic indicators in Pakistan. Data from 1972 to 2010 were used to analyze the relationship between various economic variables and poverty. The economic indicators include consumer price index, literacy rate and population growth. Head count rate was used to measure poverty. The statistical techniques used include unit root Augmented Dickey-Fuller test (for checking the stationary data) & Johansen's cointegration test for the long-run relationship. The study found the correlation between all the economic factors and poverty, which means that the economic performance indicators are pertinent predictors of poverty. This can help in developing poverty alleviation strategies.

TI INDIVIDUAL INVESTORS PERCEPTION OF DIVIDENDS: PAKISTAN'S PERSPECTIVE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE cash dividend; stock dividend; dividend theories; behavioral finance;
   investor perception
ID DISAPPEARING DIVIDENDS; POLICY
AB This research paper argue that there exists a strong preference for dividends among investors. The main purpose is to find the factors that lead individual investors to reveal their preference for either cash or stock dividends. The most important dividend theories are employed to test the behavior of Pakistani individual investors towards dividends. The results reveal strong evidence that individual investors in Pakistan want dividends either in the form of cash or stocks. They also have a strong preference for dividend even if a company has to pay it by borrowing.

TI PSYCHOLOGICAL FACTORS, INFORMATION ASYMMETRY AND INVESTMENT
   DECISION-MAKING
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE behavioral finance; intentions; investing; Big Five; information
   asymmetry
ID PLANNED BEHAVIOR; MONEY; ATTITUDES
AB This study examines the impact of several psychological antecedents along with information asymmetry on short-term investment intentions. The effects of specific personality traits are also evaluated. Our results indicate that individuals, who are higher in risk aversion, tend to engage in short-term investing. Individuals, who are more open to experience and conscientious, engage in short-term investing. Our results also demonstrate that in case of larger information asymmetry, individuals tend to engage in short-term investment.

TI CAUSAL RELATIONSHIP OF EXCHANGE RATE, BALANCE OF PAYMENT, AND MONEY
   SUPPLY WITH STOCK RETURNS: CASE OF PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE stock return; balance of payment; money supply; exchange rate; causal
   relationship
ID CAPITAL-MARKETS; TIME-SERIES; UNIT-ROOT; PRICES
AB The purpose of this study is to investigate the causal relationship of exchange rate, balance of payment and money supply with stock return. The study uses Johansen & Juselius (1990) cointegration test and Granger causality test to find out the long-term and short-term relationship among the variables. The results show that only exchange rate has a unidirectional relationship with stock return. No causal relationship is found between stock returns, balance of payments, and money supply.

TI EVALUATING PERFORMANCE OF TEACHERS IN MANAGEMENT EDUCATION: GENDER
   ASPECT
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE teacher performance; student satisfaction; Leary's model
AB The purpose of this research is to evaluate which gender teacher performs better in universities of Pakistan. This study aims to examine communication skills among teachers and to what extent students are satisfied with their teachers. This paper uses an instrument called QTI (questionnaire on teacher interaction) to measure the communication skills of teachers. Gender-based diversity and performance among teachers is evaluated. The teachers were evaluated on 8 traits of Leary's model. The principal implication of this research paper is that the teacher hiring authority at universities will come to know which gender teacher should be hired to maximize student satisfaction and for better outcomes for a university.
C1 Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI INTERNET BANKING SERVICES AND COLLECTIVIST CULTURE: PAKISTANI YOUTH
   MARKET PERSPECTIVE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE youth behavior; internet banking services; theory of reasoned actions;
   perceived media richness; subjective norm
ID PLANNED BEHAVIOR; TECHNOLOGY ACCEPTANCE; USER ACCEPTANCE; ADOPTION;
   MODELS
AB The technology is changing rapidly and so is the behavior of people. New technologies are changing the lifestyle of people. Ample research on evaluating the behavior of people and how they adopt new technologies has been carried out. This study makes an attempt to evaluate the factors that make the youth adopt Internet banking services. In order to do this, extended technology acceptance model is used. TI ROLE OF ORGANIZATIONAL COMMITMENT, ORGANIZATION CITIZENSHIP BEHAVIOR,
   CAREER GROWTH, ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY TO CHANGE IN ORGANIZATIONAL
   PERFORMANCE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE career growth; OCC; organizational commitment; organization citizenship;
   organizational performance
ID MISSING LINK; QUALITY; SUPPORT
AB There is considerable research available on organizational commitment and organizational citizenship behavior with relation to organizational performance. Little evidence is found in literature about the relationship between career growth and its impact on organization commitment, organizational citizenship behavior (OCB), and organizational performance. Organizational capacity to change (OCC) is a dynamic concept. This research study tries to fill the gap in literature by testing OCC with organizational performance with other constructs. A sample of 261 employees from the development sector organizations participated in the study using a stratified sampling method. The structural equation model has been used to test the dimensions of the constructs. The results of the analysis show positive relation of organizational commitment, OCB and OCC on organizational performance. A strong relation between career growth and organizational performance is also found.
C1 [Nadeem, Muhammad; Sheraz, Adil] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Balooch, Muhamad Farooq] SZABIST, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI ANTECEDENTS AND CONSEQUENCES OF PERCEIVED CHANGE AT WORKPLACES
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE perceived change; workplace; participation; training
ID ORGANIZATIONAL CULTURE; MANAGEMENT; COMMITMENT; STRATEGIES; IMPACT
AB This study develops a model to find the impact of factors that play a significant role during the change process at workplace. Communication, participation, training, and culture are leading factors, framing perception of employees, while bringing change. The results show that all the factors were highly significant toward perceived change. Culture as an important variable affects the perceptions of employees towards change at the workplace.

TI A STUDY OF MUTUAL FUND SELECTION BEHAVIOR
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE mutual fund; investment decision; selection behavior; fund attributes
ID PERFORMANCE; PERSISTENCE
AB Investor behavior has become an emerging issue in behavioral finance. This paper attempts to study the behavior of mutual fund investors. It aims at investigating preferences for selecting a particular mutual fund, and identifying the important areas of mutual funds that appeal to investors while making investment decisions. Individual investors of listed mutual fund companies at Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) were the target population. The response of subjects was collected through a structured questionnaire. Independent sample t-test and analysis of variance (ANOVA) were used for data analysis. Individual investor selection behavior is significantly different on the basis of demographics.

TI LOCUS OF CONTROL VS. FUNDAMENTALS IN INVESTORS' DECISION-MAKING
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE investor; investment; investment decision; fundamentals of investment;
   representativeness bias; adjustment and anchoring bias; leniency bias
ID MODERATE PREDICTION; INFORMATION; PSYCHOLOGY; EMOTIONS; RISK
AB Investment decisions are not only influenced by their fundamentals but by different factors. One of the factors is locus of control of any investor to their investment decision, locus of control depends on introverts and extroverts, because most of investors use them as heuristic for investment decisions instead of fundamentals. Keeping this in view, this paper shows how cognitive biasness (i.e. representativeness, adjustment and anchoring, leniency) effects investment decisions over fundamentals.

TI HOW BUSINESS ETHICS, ORGANIZATIONAL COMMITMENT AND TRUST AFFECT TEAM
   PERFORMANCE
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE business ethics; trust; organization; working in teams
ID INTERPERSONAL-TRUST; JOB-ATTITUDES
AB Business ethics is an application of general ethical principles to business dilemmas and encompasses a broader range of issues and concerns. This paper attempts to analyze the relations of independent variable including trust, organizational commitment and business ethics with the dependent variable team performance. There is a need to enhance awareness of ethics from top to bottom in every organization. In every situation an organization needs commitment and trust to increase its performance also following ethical practices. When an organization provides this sort of flexibility, then employees automatically treat their workplace as a home where they would be more committed to fulfilling their duties and responsibilities.

TI EXTENDING THE IS STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT MODEL: A STUDY FROM THE PERSPECTIVE
   OF SERVICE INDUSTRIES
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE IS strategic alignment; resource-based view (RBV); environment; realized
   business strategy; realized IS strategy; service industry
ID RESOURCE-BASED VIEW; INFORMATION-TECHNOLOGY; COMPETITIVE STRATEGY;
   MANUFACTURING STRATEGY; BUSINESS PERFORMANCE; ENVIRONMENT; ORIENTATION;
   FIT; MANAGEMENT; PATTERNS
AB A contribution by many researchers focus on strategic fit between IS strategy and business strategy and positively tests its impact on performance. But limited studies take into account internal and external environmental forces during the realization of strategies. Therefore, the objective of this study is to extend the existing models of strategic alignment and include such factors. The study proposes a conceptual model that adds two new linkages of environment and resources in existing literature on IS strategic alignment. The first part of the model proposes a relationship between environment and strategies (business strategy and IS strategy); and among business resources and strategies. Whereas the second part proposes the relation of IS strategic alignment and organizational performance. The proposed model also suggests that strategic alignment of business strategy and IS strategy is a better predictor of performance than business strategy alone. It is a qualitative study which provides conceptual groundwork to test the proposed model empirically in future studies.
C1 [Khan, Sana Akbar; Qureshi, Salman Ali] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Khan, SA (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI COMBINING ENVIRONMENT, RESOURCES, AND STRATEGIES: A DESCRIPTIVE ANALYSIS
   OF SERVICE INDUSTRY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE business strategy; IS strategy; environment; resources; business
   performance
ID INFORMATION-TECHNOLOGY; BUSINESS PERFORMANCE; ALIGNMENT; ORIENTATION
AB The purpose of the study is to measure statistically the degree of environmental change and availability of resources for implementing business and IS strategies in service sector. The study combines environmental factors and strategic alignment model in a single study. Primary data were collected through structured questionnaires using purposive sampling technique from 117 top managers of business units. The results of the study show that managers perceive environmental turbulence and provide the availability of resources for a success of strategies. IS strategies support business strategies, resultantly improve business performance of service organizations.

TI ENVIRONMENTAL FORCES AND IS STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT MODEL: AN EMPIRICAL
   STUDY OF SERVICE INDUSTRY IN PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE IS strategic alignment; resources; environment; performance
ID INFORMATION-TECHNOLOGY; MANUFACTURING STRATEGY; BUSINESS PERFORMANCE;
   COMPETITIVE STRATEGY; ORIENTATION; FIT
AB This study examines the impact of external environment and internal resources on business and IS strategy. It also tests the impact of IS strategic alignment on business performance. The results show a positive and significant relation between both environmental forces and strategies. The study also supports a significant positive relationship between IS strategic alignment and business performance, but does not support a significant relation between business strategy and performance.

TI ORGANISATIONAL CULTURE: THE BREEDING GROUND FOR ACHIEVING COMPETITIVE
   ADVANTAGE IN THE BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT OF THE 21ST CENTURY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE total quality management; organisational culture; competitive advantage
ID PERFORMANCE; TQM
AB This study argues that in order to gain competitive advantage TQM and knowledge management are the key processes. TQM is achievable through top management and employees, while knowledge management is about sharing which can only be achieved through motivation and trust. Organizational cutlure has a strong influence on creating and maintaining competitive advantage through inculcating TQM and knowledge sharing.

TI COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: THE ROLE OF ORGANISATIONAL INTANGIBLES
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE competitive advantage; feminist approach; innovativeness; culture;
   diversity
ID OPPORTUNITY
AB This research paper aims to build up the concept of competitive advantage, with a very different approach and combination of organizational intangibles. These intangibles are leadership, workforce diversity, feminist approach to culture and the role of intrinsic approach to motivating employees. Flexible leadership style, diversity at different levels of management, 'sameness' approach to culture for handling gender differences, and motivating employees from inside are discussed in a logical manner. The findings of this paper are a contribution that would lead to understanding competitive advantages with different blending of organisational intangibles.

TI RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DISTRIBUTIVE JUSTICE, INTERACTIONAL JUSTICE, JOB
   SATISFACTION, TEAM COMMITMENT AND ORGANIZATIONAL JUSTICE: A
   CROSS-CULTURAL STUDY OF NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS IN SUDAN AND PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE distributive justice; interactional justice; job satisfaction; team
   commitment; organizational citizenship behavior
ID CITIZENSHIP BEHAVIOR; EMPLOYEE CITIZENSHIP; PROCEDURAL JUSTICE;
   MULTIFOCI APPROACH; SOCIAL-EXCHANGE; CLEANUP TIME; PERCEPTIONS;
   ENVIRONMENT; INTERDEPENDENCE; ANTECEDENTS
AB The purpose of this study is to explore how different factors contribute to developing and increasing organizational citizenship behavior in non-profit organizations. The results reveal that organizational justice promotes organizational citizenship behavior. Furthermore, a key finding is that team commitment plays a positive mediating role between job satisfaction and organizational citizenship behavior.

TI THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ETHICAL LEADERSHIP, LEADER-MEMBER EXCHANGE,
   PERCEIVED ORGANIZATIONAL SUPPORT, ORGANIZATIONAL CULTURE AND
   ORGANIZATIONAL CITIZENSHIP BEHAVIOR
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE ethical leadership; organizational culture; perceived organizational
   support; leader-member exchange; organizational citizenship behavior
ID INDIVIDUALISM-COLLECTIVISM; PERFORMANCE
AB The purpose of the study is to explore how ethical leadership, organizational culture, perceived organizational support, as well as leader-member exchange contribute to organizational citizenship behavior. This survey was conducted on the cellular industry of Pakistan. Data was collected through self-administered questionnaires and 322 responses were received. The results of the survey have shown that ethical leadership, perceived organizational support and organizational culture have a positive relationship with organizational citizenship behavior. The findings suggest that leader-member exchange plays a positive mediating role between ethical leadership and organizational citizenship behavior.
C1 [Sheraz, Adil; Nadeem, Muhammad] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Khan, Muhammad Aslam] Preston Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI MODELING LINK BETWEEN TRANSFORMATIONAL, TRANSACTIONAL LEADERSHIP AND
   ORGANIZATIONAL CITIZENSHIP BEHAVIOR BY MEDIATING ETHICAL LEADERSHIP
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE transformational leadership; transactional leadership; ethical
   leadership; organizational citizenship behavior
ID VALUES
AB This research has investigated the relation between ethical leadership with transformational leadership, transactional leadership, as well as organizational citizenship behavior. The study found that transformational leadership and contingent rewards and management by exception, active dimensions of transactional leadership, have positive and strong association with ethical leadership and organizational citizenship behavior. It is also found that ethical leadership plays a positive mediating role between transformational/transactional leadership and organizational citizenship behavior. The results of this study have high importance for organizations and future researches on ethical leadership and organizational citizenship behavior.

TI IMPACT OF TRANSFORMATIONAL AND SERVANT LEADERSHIP ON ORGANIZATIONAL
   PERFORMANCE: A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE servant leadership; organizational performance; transformational
   leadership
ID MARKET ORIENTATION; COMMITMENT; INNOVATION; MODEL; WORK
AB The purpose of this study is to examine the impact of two comparative leadership styles on the organizational performance outcomes. The leadership styles undertaken are the transformational and servant leadership. A sample of 155 participants is taken from the profit-oriented service sector of Pakistan. The result shows that transformational leadership has more impact on organizational learning than servant leadership. Furthermore, organizational learning enhances the organizational performance.

TI CRITICAL ELEMENTS OF THE CONSTRUCTIVE PERFORMANCE FEEDBACK: AN
   INTEGRATED MODEL
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE performance feedback; performance appraisal; work related attitudes
AB This paper tries to increase the conceptual understanding about what an effective performance feedback mechanism of an organization should consist of. The paper gives an integrated framework in the form of a model for better understanding performance feedback elements. A synthesis of existing literature on performance feedback in the form of research papers, consultations and training reports identify critical elements of reinforcing feedback. The results of this article are beneficial to guide ongoing research in the area on effective performance appraisals in general and performance feedback in particular.

TI SUPPORTIVE LEADERSHIP ELEVATES THE SPIRIT OF ORGANIZATION COMMITMENT: A
   CONCEPTUAL STUDY
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE psychological empowerment; organizational learning; supportive
   leadership and organizational commitment
ID LEARNING ORGANIZATION; EMPOWERMENT; VALIDITY; MODEL; PERSPECTIVE;
   TURNOVER
AB Commitment leads towards the success of every organization. The aim of performance management is to improve employee commitment and loyalty to an organization. It also means to inculcate organizational goals, values, behavior, and culture into the hearts and souls of employees, so that every individual acts as an integral component of that goal attaining team. Research work suggests that psychological empowerment enhances the level of organizational commitment. This study suggests that to maximize the concept of synergy, participative work environment, and to make an accelerating strategic organization, the role of supportive leadership should be given space as a procedural requirement in statutes and regulations of every organization.

TI CROSS-CULTURAL COMPARISON OF HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS FACULTY IN
   PAKISTAN AND MALAYSIA
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE cross-cultural; higher education; faculty; organizational commitment;
   turnover; stress
ID JOB INSECURITY; ORGANIZATIONAL COMMITMENT; SATISFACTION; MANAGEMENT;
   PEOPLE
AB This study tends to examine the relationship between organizational commitment, P-O fit, fairness, stress, job insecurity, and turnover intentions between higher education faculty in Pakistan and Malaysia. The data were collected from 135 higher education faculties in public sector of both countries. The findings suggest a positive and significant relationship between organizational commitment, P-O fit and fairness. However, work stress, job insecurity, turnover intentions are negatively and significantly associated with these variables. By comparing the results of two countries, independent sample T-test indicates there is no significant difference in organizational commitment, P-O fit and fairness, job insecurity, stress and turnover intentions between Pakistani and Malaysian higher education faculties.
C1 [Khattak, Uzma; Khan, Muhammad Asif; Rehman, Ijaz Ur] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Khattak, U (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI ORGANIZATIONAL COMMITMENT AND TURNOVER INTENTIONS BETWEEN PUBLIC AND
   PRIVATE SECTORS IN PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE organizational commitment; turnover; private and public sectors
ID JOB-PERFORMANCE; METAANALYSIS; ANTECEDENTS; CONSEQUENCES
AB The purpose of the study is to assess organizational commitment and turnover intentions among public and private sector employees in Pakistan. The study examines the attitudinal differences among organizations. The attitudinal variable is organizational commitment and behavioral variable is turnover intention. The primary data was collected from Pakistan renowned organizations, which included Pakistan Railways, PIA, WAPDA, PTCL, and Attack Refinery. The major findings are: (a) there is no significant difference in organizational commitment of both sectors, (b) the organizational commitment is high among male employees than female in private sector, (c) there is no significant difference in organizational commitment of public sector employees, (d) turnover intentions are high in private sector as compared to public sector in Pakistan, (e) there is no significant difference among male and female turnover intentions in both sectors.
C1 [Khattak, Uzma] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Khan, Muhammad Aslam] Preston Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI MEASURING POF AND PJF OF BANKING SECTOR PROFESSIONALS IN PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE person-organization fit; person-job fit; turnover; performance
ID PERSON-ORGANIZATION FIT; JOB
AB Skilled employees are the most valuable asset of any organization. The retention of this valuable asset is important for long-term organizational success. The purpose of ongoing research is to examine whether person-organization fit (POF) and person-job fit (PJF) significantly correlate to employee effective performance (EEP) in banking sector, and whether these two and EEP predictors predict turnover intention (TI). A total of 317 employees from 7 banks participated. A self-administered questionnaire was used to collect the data. The results support the hypotheses that POF and PJF significantly correlate to EEP and TI.

TI AFFINITY WITH COMPUTERS AND PERCEIVED TRUSTWORTHINESS AS DETERMINANTS OF
   INTERNET PURCHASE IN FASHION OUTLETS
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE affinity with computers; perceived trustworthiness; fashion clothing
ID USER ACCEPTANCE; TECHNOLOGY; TRUST; QUALITY
AB With the advent of technology and the rise of Internet, marketers depict it as a vast laboratory, launching a series of experiments to crack the code that generates a golden key in the form of sales and customer loyalty. Success comes not that easy, not surprisingly most failed. This study focuses on the Internet purchases in fashion clothing outlets. The results are in compliance with the previous studies done in developed countries and reveal that there is a huge prospect of Internet purchase in the fashion clothing industry of developing country such as Pakistan.

TI TESTING THE ARBITRAGE PRICING THEORY: EVIDENCE FROM PAKISTAN
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE arbitrage pricing theory; inflation; exchange rate; money supply; oil
   prices
ID SELECTION; MARKET; RISK
AB This study aims at testing the validity of arbitrage pricing theory in Pakistani economy using macroeconomic variables (inflation, exchange rate, money supply (M1) and oil prices). Exchange rate is taken as Pak Rupee against US Dollar. Convenience sampling technique is used to locate the sample and monthly returns for 5 years (2004-2008) for 26 companies listed on Karachi Stock Exchange constitute the sample for this study. Regression is run for all 26 companies individually using stock return as dependent variable and all the macroeconomic factors as independent variables. This yielded the sensitivity of stock prices to each macroeconomic variable (beta) which were in turn used to calculate the projected values for all companies in the sample. T-test is used to compare the actual and projected stock returns. The results show no significant difference between two value sets thereby concluding that arbitrage pricing theory is valid for predicting future stock returns.
C1 [Ullah, Waseem] Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Naz, Iram; Khan, Habib Hussain] Muhammad Ali Jinnah Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.
RP Ullah, W (reprint author), Iqra Univ, Islamabad, Pakistan.

TI LINKAGES OF RISK MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND ORGANIZATIONAL PERFORMANCE:
   EVIDENCE FROM PAKISTAN TELECOM SECTOR
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE risk management; organizational petformance; telecom sector
AB This study examines the effect of risk management practices on organizational performance of Pakistan's telecom sector; specifically cellular mobile operators. The entire population of 5 firms has been selected and the results are informative about the signcance of risk management practices. The findings reveal that organizations with risk management practices have significant control over uncertainties and their predictive ability helps in timely development of contingency plans to stop erosion of organizational income; thereby improving their organizational performance. The findings also support that the integration of RM practices and organizational objectives facilitates the achievement of optimal organizational performance.

TI IMPACT OF HR PRACTICES, EMPOWERMENT AND ORGANIZATIONAL CULTURE ON
   RETENTION AND PERFORMANCE OF ORGANIZATION
SO ACTUAL PROBLEMS OF ECONOMICS
LA English
DT Article
DE employees empowerment; HR practices; organizational culture; employees
   retention; organizational performance
ID JOB-SATISFACTION; EMPLOYEE TURNOVER; INVOLVEMENT; COMMITMENT;
   CONSEQUENCES; DETERMINANTS; MODEL
AB People are the most valuable asset and can help organization to achieve sustainable competitive advantage. The current study investigates the relationship among HR practices, empowerment and organizational culture on retention and performance of organizations. Hypotheses testing using structural equation modeling show a positive impact of HR practices, empowerment and organizational culture on employee retention and performance of organizations. The finding of the study reinforces the idea that increasing employee retention improves performance of organizations.
